semantic_identifier: 9987276 - Bayfront Helix Genetics - sales_pitch - Discussion with Rania Saleh

hierarchy.meeting_title: 9987276 - Bayfront Helix Genetics - sales_pitch - Discussion with Rania Saleh

sections.text: Irene Shen: Hi Rania—thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep this brief. I’m Irene. I work with teams that get a lot of customer-reported issues coming in from Zendesk, Intercom, emails, and internal notes, and they struggle to turn that noise into something engineering and CS can actually act on.
Rania Saleh: Hi Irene. Sure, but I only have a few minutes. What is this about exactly?

Irene Shen: Totally. The product is called Issue_Tracker. It sits between your support channels and delivery tools like Jira or Linear, and it standardizes an “issue object”—so instead of hundreds of tickets that all say the same thing differently, you get deduped clusters like “Sample upload fails on Safari” with evidence, impacted customers, and links back to the original tickets and conversations.
Rania Saleh: We already have Zendesk and Jira. We do some tagging and reporting. How is this different?

Irene Shen: Great question. Tagging helps, but it usually breaks down when wording varies or when multiple teams use different tags. Issue_Tracker’s issue_clustering automatically groups raw inputs using semantic similarity plus rules you control—like product area, platform, severity, or keywords—so you can see “this is actually one underlying problem” even if it came in through 40 tickets and a couple CSM notes.
Rania Saleh: Okay. But we’re not looking to add another system that people have to maintain.

Irene Shen: That’s exactly what we try to avoid. It doesn’t replace Zendesk or Jira—those remain the systems of record. Issue_Tracker links back to them. The workflow is typically: clusters get created automatically, someone can quickly merge or split with guardrails, and then you connect a cluster to an existing Jira ticket or create one. After that, everyone sees the same status without manually stitching together spreadsheets or searching through ticket threads.
Rania Saleh: Who on our side would actually use it day to day?

Irene Shen: Usually Support Ops or a triage lead owns the clustering review, but CSMs get a lot of value too. One common use case: CSMs subscribe key accounts to specific clusters—so if Bayfront Helix Genetics has a few strategic customers hitting the same issue, you can track which customers are impacted and make follow-up consistent. When the linked Jira ticket ships, Issue_Tracker records the release milestone and keeps a history of who was notified and when.
Rania Saleh: We do customer follow-up now—CSMs just watch Jira tickets and keep notes.

Irene Shen: Makes sense. The gap we see is that Jira is built around engineering work items, not customer impact. Issue_Tracker keeps the issue cluster tied to the source evidence and affected accounts, so you can answer: “How widespread is this? Which segments are impacted? Are we underestimating it because it’s spread across channels?” And your CSMs don’t have to hunt for status or wonder which customers they already updated.
Rania Saleh: I get the concept, but our volume isn’t enormous. Also, we’re in a regulated environment—anything touching customer data gets scrutinized.

Irene Shen: Understood. On volume, even moderate volumes can hide trends because the same problem shows up with different phrasing. The clustering is mostly about surfacing the true “theme count” and making prioritization defensible. On data, we can scope what’s ingested—some teams start with metadata and summaries rather than full transcripts, and keep the links pointing back to Zendesk where permissions already live.
Rania Saleh: We’d still need security review, and honestly we’re slammed this quarter. I’m not sure we can take on a new tool rollout.

Irene Shen: That’s fair. Just to calibrate—when issues come in today, do you have a consistent way to dedupe across Support tickets versus CSM notes, and then show engineering “this is one cluster impacting these specific accounts”?
Rania Saleh: Not really. We do weekly triage and we try our best, but it’s manual. Still, it works “well enough,” and we have bigger priorities right now.

Irene Shen: Got it. If the status quo is acceptable, it may not be worth the change management. The reason I asked for time is that teams often realize they’re missing revenue risk or repeat churn drivers because the evidence is fragmented. Issue_Tracker makes the volume and trends visible, and it reduces duplicate triage work.
Rania Saleh: That’s interesting, but I’m not the owner of Support Ops, and my leadership is very cautious about adding platforms. Also, we just renewed some tooling—budget is tight.

Irene Shen: Completely understood. Would it help if I shared a one-page overview showing how the issue_clustering works and the CSM subscription/follow-up workflow, and you can forward it to whoever owns triage? If it resonates, we could do a deeper call later.
Rania Saleh: You can send it, but I can’t promise we’ll review it soon. And I don’t want to set up another meeting right now.

Irene Shen: No problem. To make it relevant, is there a specific pain you’ve had recently—like recurring bugs that keep coming back across tickets, or customers asking for the same feature and it’s hard to quantify?
Rania Saleh: We have recurring themes, sure, but we’re managing. Our immediate focus is internal delivery and compliance work. New process is a hard sell.

Irene Shen: That’s clear. I’ll keep this lightweight: I’ll email a short overview and a couple screenshots of what a cluster looks like—naming suggestions, representative examples, and how it links back to Zendesk and Jira—so you can quickly judge if it’s worth revisiting next quarter.
Rania Saleh: Okay, send it over. But again, we’re not committing to anything.
Irene Shen: Absolutely. What’s the best email for you, and should I copy whoever owns Support Ops or customer experience tooling at Bayfront Helix Genetics?
Rania Saleh: Use my work email—you should have it from the invite. Don’t copy others yet; I’ll decide if it’s worth passing along.

Irene Shen: Perfect. Thanks, Rania. I’ll send that today, and I won’t push for a meeting. If in a few months you’re revisiting how you dedupe issues and track customer follow-up tied to Jira releases, I’d be happy to reconnect.
Rania Saleh: Sounds good. Thanks for keeping it short.
